newsitem.title: USA: GTE Q4 results impress analysts.
newsitem.headline: GTE Q4 results impress analysts.

text.p: Fourth quarter results from GTE Corp on Tuesday impressed analysts with the company's ability to improve its core businesses while simultaneously expanding into long distance services.
"All the trends are in place for double digit earnings growth into the future,' said Barry Sine of SBC Warburg.

GTE reported an eight percent jump in local access lines to customers -- well ahead of most rivals -- and a long distance customer base of 825,000 in its first nine months of operation, ahead of its own 750,000 target.
The company made an operating profit per share of $0.82 against $0.74 a year ago, $0.01 above the First Call analysts' consensus estimate.
The most impressive aspect was that the costs of getting into long distance did not seem to eat into the benefits of core business growth, analysts said.
"A very strong result, definitely indicating that the long distance entry is not affecting earnings momentum," said Bill Vogel of broker Dillon Read.
GTE is not a regional Bell, and so was not forced by the 1996 Telecom Act to open up its local calling areas to competition before offering long distance services.
The greater the regulatory delays for regional Bells and long distance companies to enter each others' markets, the better GTE's advantage is, analysts say.
"For the time being GTE is the only company that is getting the best of both worlds," said Vogel.
GTE also produced a very strong increase of 25 percent in U.S. cellular subscribers to a total of 3.75 million.
"That was a positive surprise," Sine said.
The stock rose 5/8 to $44-3/8 by 1115 EST/1615 GMT.
